head.title: Place Mats to Wake Up the Table

hedline.hl1: Place Mats to Wake Up the Table

abstract.p: Personal Shopper column suggests new and unusual place mats; photos (S)

block.p: A TECHNOGEL place mat made with fabric scraps and a bright chartreuse straw mat are a far cry from their plain-Jane cousins. This fall, designers are using new materials and reworking old standbys to create interesting ways to protect, as well as decorate, the dinner table.

1. Rubber circles-within-circles come in contrasting combinations of colors ($15.95 each). The inner circle can be used as a coaster or a napkin ring. At Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street).

A TECHNOGEL place mat made with fabric scraps and a bright chartreuse straw mat are a far cry from their plain-Jane cousins. This fall, designers are using new materials and reworking old standbys to create interesting ways to protect, as well as decorate, the dinner table.

1. Rubber circles-within-circles come in contrasting combinations of colors ($15.95 each). The inner circle can be used as a coaster or a napkin ring. At Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street).

2. You will need only saddle soap to clean Arte & Cuoio's Molti Fori leather place mats from Milan. Available in red (shown), chocolate brown, black, white, orange, olive green or ivory, $300 for a set of four at Galileo, 37 Seventh Avenue (13th Street). The Alessi wood salt shaker ($30) and pepper mill ($55) are at Moss, 150 Greene Street (Houston Street).

3. A chartreuse straw mat edged in black cotton fabric is $12 (also in red and robin's-egg blue) at the Terence Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue). An iron teapot from Japan is $69 at Ad Hoc Softwares, 136 Wooster Street (Houston Street).

4. Riedizioni place mats, by Louisa Cevese of Milan, have random patterns of salvaged shredded fabric between two layers of flexible polyurethane TechnoGel. Each waterproof mat is $35 at Breukelen, 68 Gansevoort Street (Greenwich Street). The Champagne flute and water glass by Nason & Moretti are blown Murano glass; $150 for three at Moss.

5. Articulated mats from South America are made of teak blocks, $66 each at Ad Hoc; also available in black cocobolo wood. Wood chopsticks in a rattan holder, $7.50, and a Japanese rice bowl made of keyaki wood, $7.50, both at Ad Hoc Softwares.

6. Slang, an Italian place mat of twisted raffia, also comes in silver-colored steel wire. Each one is slightly different; $50 at Room, 182 Duane Street (Hudson Street). A white porcelain carafe ($126) and four tea cups ($80 for the set), designed by Hella Jongerius in Holland, are from a porcelain service available at Moss.

7. Abayzing transparent plastic mats, made in Japan, have a pattern of photographic images of giant green bay leaves. Each mat is $6 at Details, 188 Columbus Avenue (69th Street). The five-inch-diameter glass bowls designed by Kaj Frank for Iitala come in light or dark green, light or dark blue or clear; $10 each at Ad Hoc.

8. Squarebles and Circules, gray-and-white translucent plastic mats, are $5 each at the MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street, (800) 793-3167. Rosenthal's white porcelain Moon pattern soup cups by Jasper Morrison are $47 each at Moss (saucers included).
